docs.lead_paragraph: Scientists studying the lethal Ebola virus say they have found how it blocks and disables the body's ability to battle infections in a discovery that should help the search for potential cures and vaccines.

headline.main: Scientists Find How 'Nefarious' Ebola Disables Immune Response
headline.print_headline: Scientists Find How 'Nefarious' Ebola Disables Immune Response

docs.snippet: Scientists studying the lethal Ebola virus say they have found how it blocks and disables the body's ability to battle infections in a discovery that should help the search for potential cures and vaccines.

docs.lead_paragraph: When Liberian-American Patrick Sawyer collapsed at Lagos airport, he brought Ebola into a potentially ideal place for the deadly virus to spread - a vast, dirty, overcrowded city where tracing carriers and their contacts is a major problem.

headline.main: Insight-Nigeria Races to Halt Ebola Spread in Overcrowded Lagos
headline.print_headline: Insight-Nigeria Races to Halt Ebola Spread in Overcrowded Lagos

docs.snippet: When Liberian-American Patrick Sawyer collapsed at Lagos airport, he brought Ebola into a potentially ideal place for the deadly virus to spread - a vast, dirty, overcrowded city where tracing carriers and their contacts is a major problem.

docs.lead_paragraph: People infected in the West African Ebola outbreak can be offered untested drugs, the World Health Organization said on Tuesday, but the scarcity of supplies has raised questions about who gets priority access to treatment.

headline.main: WHO Backs Use of Experimental Ebola Drugs in West Africa
headline.print_headline: WHO Backs Use of Experimental Ebola Drugs in West Africa

docs.snippet: People infected in the West African Ebola outbreak can be offered untested drugs, the World Health Organization said on Tuesday, but the scarcity of supplies has raised questions about who gets priority access to treatment.

docs.lead_paragraph: The executives mingled over tea and sugar cookies, and the chatter was upbeat. Their industry, they said at the conference in the Indian capital, saves lives and brings roofs, walls and pipes to some of the world's poorest people.

docs.lead_paragraph: After a month on the front line battling Ebola in a hospital in Sierra Leone, the memories that both haunt and inspire British doctor Tim O'Dempsey are of the children.

docs.lead_paragraph: The current Ebola outbreak, the largest ever, seems likely to surpass all previous known Ebola outbreaks combined, and epidemiologists predict it will take months to control.

headline.main: Tracing Ebola’s Breakout to an African 2-Year-Old
headline.print_headline: Tracing Ebola’s Breakout to a 2-Year-Old in Guinea

docs.abstract: Report published in New England Journal of Medicine traces origin of Ebola outbreak in western Africa to Gueckedou, Guinea, where 2-year-old boy died on Dec 6, 2013, of symptoms similar to the disease; eight months later, with 1,779 cases in Guinea, Sierra Leone and Liberia, including 961 deaths, and a small cluster in Nigeria, outbreak is out of control and is getting worse; epidemiologists predict it will take many months to control, and World Health Organization spokesman says thousands more health workers are needed to fight it.
docs.snippet: The current Ebola outbreak, the largest ever, seems likely to surpass all previous known Ebola outbreaks combined, and epidemiologists predict it will take months to control.

byline.contributor: Reporting was contributed by Sabrina Tavernise and Catherine Saint Louis from New York; Clair MacDougall from Monrovia, Liberia; and Elena Schneider from Washington.
byline.original: By DENISE GRADY and SHERI FINK

docs.lead_paragraph: Public health authorities are wrestling with whether and how to bring an experimental medicine to the countries in Africa afflicted with the virus.

headline.main: Ebola Drug Could Save a Few Lives. But Whose?
headline.print_headline: Ebola Drug Could Save a Few Lives. But Whose?

docs.abstract: Public health authorities wrestle with complex questions surrounding decision to possibly dispatch experimental Ebola medications to countries in Africa afflicted with virus; activists say it is wrong that extremely scarce supplies of experimental drug went to two white American aid workers, but officials acknowledge controversies over testing of drugs in developing regions, and risk of being perceived as exploiting participants.
docs.snippet: Public health authorities are wrestling with whether and how to bring an experimental medicine to the countries in Africa afflicted with the virus.

docs.lead_paragraph: Walmart is looking to grab a bigger share of the billions of health care dollars being spent in the United States and to benefit from the shifting delivery system that has resulted from the Affordable Care Act.

headline.main: In Ambitious Bid, Walmart Seeks Foothold in Primary Care Services
headline.print_headline: In Ambitious Bid, Walmart Seeks Foothold in Primary Care Services

docs.abstract: Walmart continues to make aggressive push into medical care, opening five primary care clinic locations in South Carolina and Texas; nation's largest retailer is hoping to grab larger share of billions of health care dollars being spent in light of Affordable Care Act.
docs.snippet: Walmart is looking to grab a bigger share of the billions of health care dollars being spent in the United States and to benefit from the shifting delivery system that has resulted from the Affordable Care Act.
